Definition: In this task, you will receive a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: sexual-explicit and non-sexual-explicit. A comment is considered sexual-explicit if it represents explicit sexual matters.

Comment: CIBC has a 9 month rate of 1.5% moving to 2.69% for the duration of a 4 year term.

RY has a 2.49% on a 2 year fixed.

Scotia has a 2.9% on a 5 year fixed.

Are they the same as a 18 month term at 1.99%?  No. But depending on one's needs and opinion of interest rates over the next couple of years those options could be superior in the long run.

Sure Meridian is saving people money for the next 18 months.  The question is what will they do for you when you are up for renewal? Comment: I've been riding motorcycles for 40 years. Honolulu has bad roads, terrible drivers, danger to two-wheelers everywhere. Anywhere between points A and B it's almost certainly raining. Very limited cargo capability. Can't carry kids. Two-wheelers are a lifestyle choice, not a mode of transport. You literally couldn't pay me enough to ride a bicycle here, much less me pay $3 for the privilege. Of my adult bicycling friends, here's a list of injuries: severed thumb, broken neck, broken ribs, facial lacerations requiring plastic surgery. None of them will go near a bike anymore. The bikeshare racks are entirely along the Waikiki-Kakaako corridor. Distances you could walk. Money would be better spent on overhead walkways. This really smacks of an amenity for all those fancy condo dwellers they imagine in their multi-million dollar units down there.

Comment: I think de Vos approach the argument from a party leader angle should have no place in our dispensation. Zuma is less concerned with the legality of his leadership than simply using it as a political stick. The only approach to resolve the issue is to confirm the Constitution above party political squabbles. Political parties should have rules and a constitution. However apart from stipulations eminating from the SA Constitution its enforcability is measured as all other legislation and rules.
Ours are a Constitutional Democracy. The process of election to parliament is for individual persons to identify with a party's rules which is subject to the principle of legality. There however comes a moment that the new MP appears before a judge to state under oath to uphold the Constitution and laws. From this moment the party directions comes second. Any party instruction to disregard such oath is unlawful and invalid. MP's who voted acording to party instructions did so unlawfully.

Comment: Mr. Lamoureux, perhaps the most important thing about your article (and your cooperation with Charles Wohlforth) is that it sounds like you really are being candid about the state of American health care.  My experience is that providers deliberately stay ignorant about costs--"You'll have to talk to billing"--and encourage patients not to consider it: "Don't worry, Medicare covers it and you have medi-gap coverage, too".  At "billing," they simply say it's not possible to tell you what something will cost: "We don't know what equipment they may need, or what complications might develop."  So, unlike any other economic transaction, the consumer incurs unknown financial responsibility for something he doesn't understand. I had a simple outpatient procedure done at Prov.  The bill was $35,000!  I was in the building less than 2 hours!  My insurance would pay $13,000 max.  I told the Prov billing office I simply wouldn't pay the rest.  "Oh, we write off a lot," she said airily.

Comment: Henry Ford famously hired a private army headed by an ex Naval officer to run it.  They attacked workers at off site organizing points, caused riots at pro-union demos, "visited" workers at their homes.  They were the original "goons". 

In recent years Walmart, McDonalds, Nissan, Toyota, Honda and a host of other corporations, small and large have run (and continue to run) anti-union campaigns in the workplace.  Private security companies, from Pinkerton's on, have formed the core of a transnational union busting industry that has grown ever more sophisticated since the head breaking days of the 19th century. During the height of pre-war labour radicalism in Ontario, the populist premier, Mitchell Hepburn, used public money to hire 400 goons known as "Hepburn's Hussars" to break the UAW's organizing in Oshawa.  

 It was the courts in Canada, not the government, that decided, amongst other things, that the employer has numerous unfair advantages in countering union organizing drives.

Comment: For one thing, we need to keep in mind that (unlike the beliefs of most reality show contestants) wanting something is only a small part of success. Just because we set a goal doesn't mean that it's possible -- to a large extent, we are swapping dependence on imported oil for dependence on imported energy technology -- we create little, if any of the hardware/software needed to meet the 2045 goal -- we buy it all from off-island sources. Second, the use of battery storage to solve grid shortcomings is a dirty, expensive, and bulky way to go. To fully realize the potential of renewable energy, means addressing the peak load problem - a very smart grid goes a long way to doing that, but other measures will likely be needed that work on a system wide basis. Some of these measures could be storage, but ultimately it should be eco-friendly storage (like reversible turbines for pumped storage) -- batteries, whether privately or publically owned, are pretty far down on the eco-friendly scale.

Comment: Bob didn't mention that the Peshtigo fire was started by logging operations and burned hot and heavy, like Oregon's great Tillamook fire, through thousands of cutover acres filled with logging slash. I've viewed dozens of wildfire burns and seen lots of clearcuts filled with slash, brush, and densely planted reprod that burned faster and hotter than adjacent unlogged forests . The problem is that clearcuts don't stay bare soil very long! 

When I first went to work in the forests, old timers I worked around had a saying: "If you want to put a fire out, run it up into the woods" My cabin in Southern Oregon resisted the huge Biscuit blaze because I maintained a bare soil perimeter and kept the interior acres brush and sapling free, shaded by big overhead trees that nearly all survived.

In North California, shaded and maintained fuel breaks along logging roads and highways have often been successful except in fire storms. When forest fires become fire storms, all organics are consumed!

Comment: Dave is probably correct when he writes : “The strengthening and broadening growth is expected to push inflation higher; but until the central bank is convinced that is happening, interest rates aren’t going anywhere.” However, this is a reflection of the dysfunctional decisions made in the 2016 renewal agreement; it is delusional to say, as Dave does, that “inflation is nowhere to be seen”. The 2016 renewal agreement itself acknowledged that it was hiking the target rate of inflation; due to reductions in measurement bias of the CPI, it should have been lowered to 2.0%; not doing so amounted to an easing of monetary policy. The Bank of Canada is the only G20 central bank that targets an inflation indicator that includes mortgage interest costs. The CPI excluding mortgage interest costs had an inflation rate of 1.8% in April 2017. Since 2011, even this series no longer excludes all mortgage interest costs. An index that did would have an inflation rate in excess of 1.8%.

Comment: Agree that the present is not sustainable but there are laws governing corporates so I don't think they have free reign. And capitalism has worked. The capitalist system has ensured that poverty is dramatically reduced all over the world. It is actually the most pro poor system, despite the excesses of some at the top. My fear is that we focus so much on over-legislating the 'greedy' with the aim of more 'equality' that we end up killing the golden goose that has given the world increased living standards. Sure some pulled ahead faster than others and some got wealthy illegally, so it isn't perfect. 

Let free market capitalists run the economy and let the government take care of levelling the playing field through quality free education and services. Then don't put restrictions on educated adults engaging in voluntary transactions for their ideas, time and labour. Some will flourish, some will be okay and some will flounder. 

We are either free or we are equal. We can't be both.

Comment: @basket4: 
1) All of that sounds very hard, no question.
2) In terms of real estate, young people today would gladly trade today's high prices/low rate environment for the high rates/lower multiple of income pricing of the 1980s. Why? Because if you scrimped and saved back then, you slowly got a bigger % of a down payment. Today the opposite is true - each year you sacrifice, you fall further behind. The math is shocking.

We too have moved. A full year of mat leave, while available, is simply not an option in some fast-moving professions. And given that a far larger % of employment is contract or temporary, this benefit doesn't exist. Comment: Losing a kidney isn't the problem.  Renal cancer, once it moves outside the kidney, is quite resistant to chemo.  Not referenced in the article, and not mentioned in her statement, is the fact that because the cancer has already moved beyond the kidney, she is medically Stage 4, M1.  The presence of a cancer lesion in a rib is not good.  Bone is a prime growing medium for cancer tumors.   The best outcome for Renal cancer patients comes when the cancer is localized to the kidney, and the kidney is removed.  Once Renal cancer cells have spread beyond the kidney, treatment outcomes are very poor.  The 5 year survival rate for Stage 4 is only 8%.  My cousin was diagnosed at State 3, had his kidney removed, but only lived 2 years after that.  Once the cancer was found elsewhere, it spread very quickly, and treatments were of very limited effectiveness.  I don't see how she runs for re-election.

Comment: The names of everyone charged with a crime is public.  That doesn't mean that every name is published in the media. For example, a case recently in my town where there was a serial rapist who assaulted 3 women at random -- the media reported his name with photo, because if there were other victims or witnesses, that would encourage them to come forward and help make sure the guy was taken off the streets, which he was.

Comment: "Freedom of religion" is an American right in the Bill of Rights.

It has nothing at all to do with events outside the United States, which are not regulated by the Bill of Rights.

What does bear on freedom of religion in the platform is:

"We support a progressive vision of religious freedom that respects pluralism and rejects the misuse of religion to discriminate."

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Interestingly, this country has quite a long history of responding to disasters on remote island chains  --  until the 21st century began, the US was responsible for disaster relief in Micronesia and other South Pacific islands.  And of course we respond to disasters in our territories in the Caribbean.

The important step, and one which fills me with relief, is that now we are officially recognizing that the Olympic Peninsula will require an island-chain response.  The fact that there are so many Navy assets close by, and that the Navy is planning to use them here when "the Big One" happens, is a huge advantage to us.

We still need to be prepared to be self-sufficient in our individual needs  --  food, water, and medication  --  for an unusually long time.  But now we, and the US Government, are starting to plan for the conditions we will actually be facing.  And that's the best news we could possibly receive.

Anyone, even a child, can go into a store and purchase bottles of fluoridated water - without a prescription.

There are no warnings about possible harm from drinking fluoridated bottled water or possible overexposure to fluoride ions from drinking too much water on any bottles of fluoridated water. One would OD on water long before suffering any harm from fluoride ions.

Go ahead and try to make the case for regulating fluoridated bottled water (or fluoridated public water) as a medication.

Comment: With PSE, of the $30+ million we spent on electricity, less than $200,000 was being returned to Jefferson County in wages, salaries and contracts.  

Today we return roughly $6,000,000 in PUD wages and salaries. That means local jobs.  Contracts for facilities maintenance and forestry services are going local, not to out-of-county suppliers. This means more jobs and dollars staying and working in our county.  None of our electric dollars are going to pay profits to outside investors.

As for Electricity Mix, 60% of PSE power supplying Jefferson County was derived from carbon sources - half that from coal.  Jefferson PUD power is mostly clean BPA hydro. Jefferson County continues to be among the leaders in per capita residential PV solar installation.  And our rates are very competitive with PSE's.

We have a voice, we have local control of our power - we just voted in a new PUD Commissioner.  With PSE, we had no voice.

I'd say that's pretty good - let's make it even better.

Comment: Adam isn't giving the complete picture.  When SB 21 was being debated,  Dermot Cole and several other pointed out that at low oil prices, the state would be paying out more in tax credits than it would get in production taxes. This was dismissed as scare mongering by the proponents of SB 21. But that's exactly what happened.

Under ACES the state shared paid significant tax credits at lower oil prices and received a significant reward at high oil prices. Under SB21 the state still pays significant tax credits at low prices, but Alaska doesn’t get the increasing rates at high oil prices.

Heads the oil industry wins, tails the state loses. 

The purpose of repealing SB 21 is not to go back to ACES, it's to fix the inequities of the current tax scheme.

Comment: I do not think the example Cestnik  is describing adds clarity. 

If Sally's son has no other income besides the dividends he qualifies as a dependent if she stops giving him dividends. She should also be able to claim some of his deductions for tuition and other education expenses. Rather than paying the marginal tax rate on income of 30% the net tax rate on the $20K  could be as low as 10% (the difference between the lowest marginal tax rate and the next one up which should apply to the extra income Sally declares). In this case her son would get $18K as opposed to $20 to support his education.

This example has too many moving parts and therefor does not properly reflect the outcomes of the tax changes.

Comment: You are getting your terms confused a little bit here. To put it simply, what you are describing is a private meeting between a priest and a member of the faithful. However, not every instance of a priest and a person privately discussing the discipline of the Church, the sacraments, Church teaching, etc. is an instance of "the internal forum". Read the following piece by Edward Peters to get some more background info:

https://canonlawblog.wordpress.com/2015/11/20/toward-informed-discussion-of-the-internal-forum/

Whether you use the internal or external forum in these situations you are still searching for a definitive judgement. In these cases the external forum has declared "there was a real bond of marriage". Folks on the AL side want the internal forum to be able to say "don't care what the tribunal said, we've reached an alternative decision, the marriage was invalid." Basically a private, mostly biased appeals court of 2-3 people declaring marriages null for convenience sake.

Comment: Ross:  Yes, scraped, sold, burned and I've heard of some that were buried. A good number were converted to power and had a second life as "conversions." Boats I know of that are on exhibit:  State Museum in Juneau; Pratt Museum in Homer; Museum of Transportation off the Parks Highway which also has a conversion; Lake Clark National Park in Port Alsworth; Columbia River Maritime Museum in Astoria,OR; APA Museum in Blaine, WA which is also restoring / rebuilding one to sail.  Wooden Boat Center on Lake Union in Seattle has one that sails around the lake.  City of Dillingham has one that is displayed each summer at the local cannery.  Anchorage Museum had one that it unfortunately took off display, but sent this summer to the Bristol Bay Historical Society in Naknek for display. There are some in private ownership that are still floating / sailing including the one in Homer pictured in the article.

Comment: "Sometimes, if the church finds the priest guilty of abuse but he refuses to cooperate with church authorities, there is no recourse but to defrock him. But by consigning him to a monastery, far from children, those authorities can make sure he is never again placed in a situation where he might abuse children. If the priest refuses to accept and abide by the terms set for his being monitored, the church's authorities will reopen the case, send it back to the doctrinal congregation, and he can be defrocked. This is akin to house arrest, and if he violates the terms, he can still be removed from the clerical state."

There are a lot of "ifs" in this statement, both literally and substantively. As a practical matter, bishops are ill equipped to monitor offenders effectively. Monasteries aren't prisons, and the coming and going of every resident are not tracked 24/7. Monasteries don't want to be jailers. It is unreasonable to ask bishops to do what they lack the capacity to do.

Comment: The annual housing inflation rate as measured by the Teranet HPI was 13.9% in March, up from 13.4% in April, so even if one accepts the dysfunctional way that the Canadian CPI calculates owner-occupied  housing in terms of central bank needs there is surely something wrong when the homeowners’ depreciation CPI has a 4.4% inflation rate in May, up from 3.9%, and other owned accommodation costs is at 4.1%, up from 3.5%. New housing price index data are the only data used in the CPI; even real estate commissions are proxied using new housing pricing data. However, the NHPI excludes condominium apartments, exclude existing homes and is likely still downward-biased in measuring house price inflation in major urban centres. This partly accounts for Canada’s bizarre situation: pinpointed by the BIS as the country with the most out-of-control house prices while both the Bank of Canada’s target inflation indicator and its operational guide are well under the 2% target rate.

.

Comment: Looking at Woodfibre LNG terminal for example. According to Eoin Finn, a consultant from KPMG, the electrical subsidy for Woodfibre alone will cost taxpayers  some $34 million a year, or $860 million over its 25 year lifespan. Furthermore, there is an 18 month carbon tax holiday, a heavily discounted LNG tax rate of 3.5% locked in for 25 years, natural gas royalties lowered to almost nothing, no sales tax on methane purchases and the industry as a whole gets a $200 million a year drilling credit.  All this for 100 permanent jobs at Woodfibre and no revenue guarantee despite all the subsidies. Taxpayers pay for everything: free water for shale frackers, subsidies, even the $100 million put in the LNG Prosperity Fund since it came from MSP. 

Then there's the environmental issues...

B.C. needs at least $10 per million BTU  to make a dollar due to remoteness and the high-cost of fracking shale. Global markets prices are around $7 and it's glutted. This alone make it all senseless.

Comment: The cellular companies make the same argument you do; rates are high here because it’s such a large country to service. But given Canada’s population is actually concentrated along the U.S. border (90%) I am not convinced this flies. Australia is also a large country and rates are lower there too. If the cellular companies have been the beneficiaries of public largesse in the build out of their networks then they should be willing to face competition with MVNOs etc and/or lower prices. Europe is an interesting counter example, though the gasoline analogy seems a bit of a stretch. If Canadian public transport networks offered a viable alternative to driving as in much of Europe you may find more support for higher prices (I don't mean Vancouver's bike lanes either). As for cost of living generally, Deutsch Bank ranks Canada as the 5th most expensive country in which to live based on global prices. Obviously comparisons with the US vary around the $ but the US is still cheaper.

Comment: I too have been here since before statehood and naturally have watched our state evolve over the years. Anchorage was a great place to grow up in. Even with the initial influx of people at the beginning stages of the Trans Alaska Pipeline construction, and into the era when oil actually started flowing through the pipeline, we still experienced and felt that old time, frontier, we-all-help-each-other spirit, we were all in this together, because we CHOSE to be in this together. I personally noticed a very pronounced change in attitude in the early to mid 90's. It seems as though an entire cult of outsiders started this way, and the attitude from outsiders seemed to go from "I love it here because of what it is" to "look at all this place has to offer ME".  Unfortunately, some of those outsiders that stayed were or became politicians and are having far too much influence on what is becoming a new way of life in Alaska. Todays Alaska is not what Jay Hammond envisioned.

One of the most important lessons of the brazen act of the Commission is not just Lane County government’s willingness to thwart the Oregon and U.S. constitutions at the best of industry interests, but the true grassroots power of the people of Lane County. Our national conversation is increasingly about government/corporate collusion to protect industry profits at the expense of the people and our planet. Have a look at the '97 election. The combined Reform/PC popular vote was nearly identical to the Liberal count, but the Liberals took 155 seats (a slim majority) while Reform/PC took 80.

Does that sound fair to you?

If FPTP is the price you're willing to pay for a shot at a fake "majority", then you clearly approve of 39% of voters calling the shots for 100% of us. Enjoy the Trudeau years.

If I bought a windows ultrabook with the same build quality at best buy, i'd be looking at starting price of 1000 C$ and up.

What's not to like? Well, the 2nd tier chinese pc makers like Jumper (Lenovo being top tier) are pumping out revisions every month. So this model has had 4 major changes in as many months. Luckily, I was on backorder when V3 came out and cancelled V2 at no additional cost. Its easy enough to do - it comes down to build quality of the casing and the assembly - the parts are off the shelf, the OS is windows. Since 1998[edit]
From the inception of the NICS system in 1998 through 2014, more than 202 million Brady background checks have been conducted.[21] During this period approximately 1.2 million attempted firearm purchases were blocked by the Brady background check system, or about 0.6 percent.[22] The most common reason for denials are previous felony convictions.[22]

Prosecution and conviction of violators of the Brady Act, however, is extremely rare. During the first 17 months of the Act, only seven individuals were convicted. In the first year of the Act, 250 cases were referred for prosecution and 217 of them were rejected.[23]

A 2000 study found that the implementation of the Brady Act was associated with "reductions in the firearm suicide rate for persons aged 55 years or older but not with reductions in homicide rates or overall suicide rates."[24]

Comment: Remember 2 years ago when the Cardinals won the NL Central division with 100 wins beating out the Pirates (98 wins) and Cubs (97 wins).  The Pirates and Cubs had more wins than either of the other 2 NL division winners. I think the 2nd wild card was great for that scenerio however it was a shame one of those great teams only had a 1 game playoff stint. As I recall the reason for the 2nd wild card to was almost force the 2 wild card teams to use their ace in the wild card playoff game so they would go into the next series at a slight disadvantage.  When there was just 1 wild card team, that team often went far into the playoffs because they often had the momentum of playing competitive games through the end of the season while division winners typically rested players after clinching and lost their mojo. Examples- Rockies 2007 got to the WS. Angels 2002 won the WS. Those are the 2 that immediately came to mind but I remember MLB being concerned that wild cards were often advancing far.

Comment: Given all the divergent views about how best to sustainably fund State government, a solution remains elusive. Finding and defining common denominators is crucial. I'll put forth a few that perhaps most can agree on as a basis for public discourse and Legislative action going forward. 

(1) We all lose if an operating budget is not passed by July 1; a shut-down would be irresponsible and something approaching disastrous. (2) the State faces a 2 1/2 plus billion dollars shortfall. (3) the price of oil isn't going up anytime soon. (4) Tapping into CBR and PF principal is foolish and (5) you generally can't get something for nothing.

My wife and I feel lucky. We receive and appreciate the services received from State government. We pay no State income tax. We pay no State sales tax. In the Mat-Su Borough, our property taxes are quite reasonable. And we get "free" money with our annual PF dividend. But the "good times" are over, for now. It's time to man up and pay the piper.

Comment: Good read, but I'm nonetheless of the opinion that 28 pounds in only six months (that would be 56 in a year!) is way, way, way too fast, and you're never going to be able to maintain it. You managed to endure your regimen for six months, and you probably figure that now you're at a decent weight you'll be able to slack off a little and just maintain. Or maybe you're going to try to keep up the relatively boring nutritional plan, three days/wk of weights and three days/wk of running. Either way, I wish you luck. Please, please, please -- in the upcoming three years, write at least a yearly follow-up article. Anyone with sufficient will-power can hang in for six months -- that's not the test. It's what happens after that initial period of will power has been frittered away by a million day-to-day factors that tells the story. Personally, I find that any plan that loses more than 12 pounds per year is ultimately unsustainable and is setting you up for failure further down the road.

Comment: It would seem that you do not understand the concept of negative feedback.  Water clouds may increase in response to global warming thus reducing warming from what it might have been.  But the growth in clouds is in response to warming.  A mechanism of negative feedback resists change and generally reduces the rate at it would otherwise happen but does not prevent it altogether except in cases with very high effective gain.  I did not say clouds overwhelm the greenhouse effect of CO2.  I said that light back scattered by the clouds does not get red shifted to the IR as ground incident radiation largely does.  CO2 blocks IR, not visible.  Ground incident radiation is trapped by the CO2 since it gets shifted to CO2's absorptive band while cloud scattered solar radiation remains visible and thus scoots right through the CO2 and back into space.

Comment: There's quite a bit more nuance to the subject than that, but to boil it down as much as possible (as required by the limit on comment lengths), with Climate Change aside, wherever humans have an impact on a natural system, such as defending developed areas from forest fire, there is still a need for the maintenance effects of these natural agents.  It's similar to the trophic cascade that happens when you remove a top predator like wolves.  Look at the forest as a herd:  if you remove the means by which a system can regulate herd composition (ie: wolves targeting the old, sick, and weak), then another agent, such as disease, or other animals will step up and fill that niche, occasionally with highly visible effects.  Humans can potentially fill that disrupted niche by conducting proscribed burns and/or conducting selective thinning in an ecologically sound manner around human developed areas.

Rural Ontario experiences brain drain because dense cities out-compete small communities in terms of jobs.
To "fix" this, you can force people to go where no jobs are, or you can build enough housing for them in and around cities. One of these two will require intensification of the GTA, the other overrules the job/housing market and deprives newcomers of their right to choose.
You can also cancel economic growth and keep any newcomers out. To me, that solution feels neither very Canadian nor seems like a good long-term plan.
Another solution might be to invest heavily in other countries to the point where living standards there will exceed Canada's. Then we won't have the problem of motivated immigrants moving in. Once we get left behind and our kids start leaving Canada for a better future, there'll be plenty of space for everyone's oversized bungalow.

Comment: "Since the advent of the Jerry Springer show and reality TV, the lowest common denominator of American culture has been on display and we have let our standards of civility sink to an all-time low."  This seems like empty (misinformed) rhetoric.  I'd argue that civility and the lowest common denominator was lower in times past. Think what things might have been said by supporters of slavery, Jim Crow, Native American genocide, public hangings, US concentration (internment) camps during WWII, etc.  I think you might be getting confused by the fact that people now have the internet: a very large, easy access soap box to stand on, and one that records everything.  The sheer volume of "uncivility" that one can witness is greater now than ever, but does that mean the ratio to US population is greater or discourse is less civil? I argue no.  I appreciate your sentiment, but be mindful that a robust political discourse is essential to democracy. Civility for civility's sake get's us nowhere.

Comment: Oh my! Seven no's, I guess you win, since that beats an actual argument.

A "no position" is indeed just that. Cook treats it as if it does not exist and dismisses it, when in fact it constitutes nearly two thirds of the actual scientific concensus. I did not claim it represents dissent, just that it represents an unwillingness or inappropriateness towards taking any position, indicating those authors are following the science, which is clearly far from settled. The Cook study's main value is that it exposes that about a third of climate scientists have abandoned objectivity on the side of AGW. You will notice very few on the other side have done that according to Cook's data. I could criticize Cook for other major failures in his poor handling of self ratings as well as failure to explicitly control for bias of raters, and more, but what is the point when he threw out two thirds of the data and drew his conclusions from only that which suited his predrawn purposes. What a hack.

Comment: Joey, you do not understand my argument.  Insurance companies do insure healthy people with the promise of protecting them financially and medically if they become sick.  They are betting that you will not become sick.  You are covering your health and finances in the event that you do.  Insurance companies have countless mathematical tables detailing risk for people with life style habits, pre-existing medical conditions, weight, age, marital status and everything else they think will effect the policy they sell.  They will price the policy (or not) according to that information. Young jogging females are a better risk than fat old men who smoke.  Life insurance and auto insurance work in similar ways.   Obamacare turned this upside-down. 
The government has no pool for pre-existing conditions.  Medicare is an insurance policy paid by workers until retirement who are then forced into a government health care system.   
I think there should be separate government subsidies.

Comment: I'm not a scientist and have never studied the chemical compositions of either, but I've heard - from a great many people, who are far more knowledgeable on the subject than I - that there is a significant difference between CBD hemp oil and CBD cannabis oil.  My common sense explanation is that there must be a difference if one is permissible through USDA (CBD hemp oil) and the other isn't (CBD cannabis oil).  
 
With one lab and regulations/processes still tied up in the long halls of bureaucracy, I don't suspect that local dispensaries have had an opportunity to test their cannabis and manufactured cannabis products.  Hawai'i law requires that manufactured cannabis products be permitted and I have yet to see the DOH rules that provide those permits/permissible uses.   

I don't think you give enough credit to locals, who have had to tap into their own resourcefulness for medical cannabis for - arguably - a great many decades.  You also don't need a dispensary for CBD hemp oil.

Comment: I only used maths to demonstrate that there are many areas (not limited to maths) where one answer is held to be correct to the exclusion of all others...I did not intend for it to be entirely analogous to the basis of religious belief...because maths, rather uniquely, can use its own internal rules of logic to prove further rules of logic...however, that said, even maths is dependent on holding to fundamental, unprovable axioms. Furthermore, most of our lives is lived outside of a realm of rigorous proof: you can't prove that your mother loves you (in the same way that you can prove a mathematical theorem - you can only draw conclusions on the basis of past experiences), you can't prove what your favourite music is etc...in fact most of our daily actions are informed by our past experience, rather than by following some rigorous mathematical-style proof or logic....and basing future actions on past experience is a form of faith!

Comment: Just for once, look at the issue dispassionately. A person who joins the military and then decides to switch genders, puts the military on the hook for the whole nine yards. That's the medical treatment itself, which can be costly and easily last for over a year, as well as the even longer period in which the service member is unavailable for duty. And that doesn't even consider the group personnel issues that can arise in a military environment.

Putting a hold on additional transgendered persons joining the military is a reasonable step. In the meantime any effects rising from the current transgendered military personnel can be examined. In the meantime, serving transgendered personnel must not be discriminated against in any way. Further down the road, an evidence-based policy can be instated.

Comment: While I certainly applaud this new program, I believe that the R-G's gushing editorial is rather misleading. I believe that it has been many years since any significant number of low-level offenders, as referred to in the editorial, have been prosecuted in juvenile court, let alone held in detention. The reason is simple to understand; money. With the county supplying very limited funding, both to the juvenile department and the DA's office, the focus has been on juveniles engaged in much higher level criminal activity. This, of course, makes sense when there are limited resources. 

So, while this new program may provide some additional resources to deal with low-level offenders, people should not expect that it is going to save any appreciable amount of money. Of course the most important question is whether this will have any demonstrative impact on recitivism. Designed properly, the program may provide the answer in a few years.

Comment: Some of my fondest memories of growing up in Arlington included going to get a hair cut with my father, a WW II Vet, at Willie's barbershop on Olympic Avenue. Willie was a WWII vet with tattoos on his arms. The men would shoot pool in the back room of the barber shop, drink beer, talk about their war and about their sons who were in Vietnam like my brother, talk about home life, and generally act like real men. 

We always got a kick out of the time the City attempted to get Willie to re-paint his business as part of idea of turning Arlington into another Winthrop style town. Willie painted smiley faces over the entirety of his building in an act of rebellion.

That is when Arlington was still a timber and hippie town, when men were real men, and a kid knew all of the unique people by name who made Arlington & Darrington a great place to live.

Comment: People taking out loans that they subsequently failed to repay was what led to the economic crisis.  Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank didn't issue mortgages themselves in the U.S. - they purchased and then re-sold existing mortgages to further investors without disclosing the poor quality of the original borrowers to the new investors.  From a borrower's perspective, what makes a bad collateralized loan isn't whether the borrower can repay - it is whether the collateral can be sold for enough to make the lender whole in the event that the original borrower defaults.  If someone takes out a loan on their Roles; the pawnbroker doesn't care if they every repay their loan - the pawnbroker just sells the Rolex whenever the original borrower fails to pay.

Comment: Have you actually looked at Eugene's Zero Vision draft? It's pretty clear that the focus is to make it less likely that motorists will die at the hands of other motorists. This is because their "data", which is heavily biased towards injured motorists, indicates that the majority of roadway injuries and deaths in Eugene are motorist on motorist and that this type is increasing.

It's no big surprise that motorist-only traffic violence is increasing in Eugene. We have lost huge numbers of pedestrians, bus riders and cyclists back to their car seats over the past decade. Walking to work is down almost 30% from its peak, riding the bus is down over 50% and cycling is down over 40%. We're simply running out of soft targets and now have to settle for harder ones.

If implemented as drafted, Eugene's Zero Vision will contribute to our unprecedented loss of active transportation participation. It's another opportunity to live up to our fantastic potential squandered by the Jon Ruiz gang.

Comment: The entire dairy marketing "board"/supply management system in Canada has morphed from something originally designed to help  small family farms into something that serves corporate interests at the expense of Canadian consumers and taxpayers.  When it started in the 1950's, there were ~150,000 farmers with a quota while the population of Canada was ~15M so each farmer was producing dairy for about 100 people. Over the years, quotas became concentrated in the hands of the few and today there are ~12,000 for a population of ~36M so each corporation is serving ~3,000 people. There are very few "family" farms remaining and those with quotas are, by and large, multi-million dollar businesses so the current system supports corporate profits at the expense of all Canadian families. Worse yet, the current system results in millions of litres being dumped every year in order to help maintain artificially high prices. Time for supply management to be relegated to the dust bin of history!

Comment: Every single fund company offers "Series F" version of their funds, which have no embedded fees.  Many financial advisors use these funds and then charge a fee separately on the  account (in fact, when advice fees become dis-embedded in a couple years, all mutual funds will be sold this way).  However, the discount brokerages choose not to allow purchase of these versions.  They instead have chosen to let buyers only choose the "Series A" version, which typically pay them 1% or to allow purchase of a "Series D" version which charges 0.25%.  In the brokerage's defense, they don't charge fees on mutual fund trades.  

Note that most discount brokerage assets are managed by the Canadian banks.  That's why this is a problem.  The banks have never met a profit they don't like. So before you beat up mutual fund companies, remember that the banks are the worst offenders.

Comment: Lots of excellent letters today, thanks ADN!

However, while sympathetic, I have to disagree with Penny Burt's analysis. I don't know why house prices are rising (if they are) if people are leaving, but imagining that it's because investors are monopolizing the available houses in order to rent them out doesn't make sense to me. 

If there are more houses than people (because people are leaving), then someone won't be able to rent out the house they own as an investment -- rents will fall to try to get the marginal house rented -- and at some point rents will fall so much that someone will decide to sell the house and invest in something else. 

That is -- at least theoretically -- the market should take care of itself. If it's not, something else must be going on, but I doubt that it's because people are choosing to own houses as investments. (Full disclosure: My sister and I still own and rent out our childhood home.)

Comment: "It's not capitalism that prohibits child labor, but socialism."

I see.  So in your mind, children don't work in socialist countries like Venezuela, right?  You believe that prior to Vietnam and China embracing capitalism, children weren't working?  

You can't be intelligent AND simultaneously believe that lack of child labor is not the product of wealth accumulation.  The evidence for this is absolutely overwhelming.  Where there is poverty, there is child labor.  Where this is wealth, there is no child labor.  

Parents don't send their kids to work because they want to, they do it because it is necessary for them to survive.  This has always been the case prior to capitalism.  If "socialists" had tried to "end child labor" prior to capitalism, it would have lead to mass starvation.  Children work because they HAVE to.  Economic conditions make it necessary.  Only in capitalist societies where large amounts of wealth have been accumulated do they no longer have to.

Comment: If I take payment from someone, promise something and don't deliver, that's fraud.  So how come companies can take pension contributions from employees, promise pension benefits and then just renege without any repercussions to the companies or their overpaid management?  How can they just avoid paying legally-mandated severance pay and get away with it?  Companies should be required to fully-fund their pension and severance liabilities (i.e. maintain assets equal to their liabilities and keep them separate from company assets) at all times.  As it is, if there's a shortfall in pension funding they are only required to develop a plan to get back to full funding eventually (they seldom do), and the regulators just go along with it.  As a former employee of a pension regulator, I was always amazed at this officially-sanctioned fraud.  If nothing else, pension and severance liabilities should at least be first on the list of priorities for payment upon company dissolution.

Comment: It is impossible for Big Business or anyone else to buy land in the former homelands due to the communal tenure system. The only way Big Business can get involved in these areas is to buy produce from the small farmers who farm their ancestral land.

If anyone is allowed to grow marijuana anywhere, then obviously big commercial farmers will begin growing immediately on their own land and then this opportunity to use marijuana as a tool to help the poorest of the poor is gone.

The complication is that there are lots of middle class people who can see this opportunity and also want to make money. The question is: given that this is an wonderful opportunity to increase people's incomes, shouldn't we try to help the poorest of the poor? Or are we just going to reinforce existing inequalities by allowing marijuana farming to benefit the middle classes and the rich?

If we are thinking in the national interest, and not our own individual interests, then surely we need to help the poorest?

Not too long ago, the model for the future of the Earth was supposed to be Venus, brutally hot due to the heavy concentration of CO2 in its atmosphere. The one or two of 95 climate change scientists cited above who are honest do not attribute climate change directly to CO2 but rather to a complicated but weak argument that somehow, more CO2 triggers more water vapor, etc. etc.

Comment: This article is based upon the hand-waving predictions of people who should know better.

House prices in Vancouver have not meaningfully budged. It has been many months since the introduction of the laughably small and feeble tax on foreign passport holders wanting to buy houses. House prices in Vancouver have stubbornly remained dozens of times the average annual local salary. They have not become any more affordable for local workers.

And so that gets to the ancient question of "cui bono", which means WHO BENEFITS, in this case from spreading around all the pretend-fantasy talk about how effectively (roll eyes) the government is being in making houses affordable again?

Is it the realtors behind this disinformation campaign, who want to keep prices and commissions really high? Is it government officials who want to look effective at their jobs? Is it government officials who want the assets of themselves and their friends and family to remain really high?

Is it all of the above?

Comment: I think some of it comes from a lack of understanding our country's history. 13 colonies, all with their own governments independent of each other, joining together in a union of one nation, but still continuing with their own state governments. Each colony, or state, wanted their say in how that union would work. Every colony was equal in that union.

Some of the Constitutional Congress supported having a "King", but that was dropped in favor of a representative form of government with democratic principles. There was then a divide on whether the representatives should choose the President, or if there should be a choice by popular vote only. The argument against that was the ill-informed public having the sole say in deciding who would lead the union, our country.

A compromise was made, two houses of Congress. They then, just as many do now, had a concern for the most populated areas having disproportional say, based solely on density of that colony's population.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Comment: It is easy to use PETA as the scapegoat for the excuse.  Far easier than to look for other answers that the race committee just does not want to accept: over commercialization.   The race has transpired from an original adventure of dogsled racing to Nome into a commercial adventure with full time racers.  Throughout the year we see coverage of racers preparing for The Great Race. Advertisers utilize racers to promote everything from dog food to Iditarod raffle sales throughout the year. Racers travel to various parts of the States as celebrities. 

The race has lost the feel of a group of Alaskan mushers who on their own dime were willing to endure the hardships of the challenge on their own. Today we see live coverage on almost every mile of the trek, mushers carrying cell phones, snow machiners following racers, crowds at every check point and endless advertising throughout the coverage. The Iditarod has become a cash cow for many and thus has lost its appeal of being unique.

Comment: Has there been any mention of OIA or Outdoor Retailer offsetting their own negative impacts from the trade show? The backbone of the OR show is not the industry leading companies whose social capital aligns with their individual interests in public lands... The backbone of the OR show are trucking transport companies who deliver elaborate booth set ups, airline companies transporting company personnel, and a smattering of oversized, over branded Sprinter-type vehicles that drive to the show twice---now three times---per year. That doesn't even dive into the footprint left behind by product shipping and transport from Asia to ports in Long Beach and Los Angeles. If the industry is really going to make the jump from public lands to a more local/global issue of a changing climate environment, when will they begin to admit their own negative impacts related to fossil fuel consumption. The Denver Convention Center mentioned a carbon offset program listed on the FAQ of their website.

Comment: " I wouldn't pat our European ancestors on the back for being humanitarians after the first wave killed as much as 40 million North and South American natives." Nobody then knew they were carrying diseases the local people had no immunity for, so where does "humanitarianism" come into it?

There were some threats by some of deliberate contaminations, which may or may not have been carried out on a small scale, and some serious criminal negligence, but little evidence of a systematic policy.

Sounds a lot like the devastation that occurred in Europe when the Bubonic Plague was introduced from Asia. It killed between 30-60% of the population and reduced the world population from an estimated 450 million down to 350–375 million, and produced religious, social, and economic upheavals.

Comment: Yours is a populist argument that will never fly.  Here's why:

- Civil servants' voting rights are a Charter issue now; it should be held separate from any election reform movement,
- The AG is an appointed position.  If you're interested in a democracy, no appointed position should be allowed to wield legislative power; that is the domain of an elected lower House,
- Recall has precedence in judicial rulings that refute pre-election political promises becoming post-election obligations.  Also, remember that MP(P)s other than Independents are representatives of their Party.  If you recall an MP(P), you effectively recall the entire Party, which could trigger a general election.  There's probably some rule or ruling that constrains bringing down a Government to the will of Parliament, not the will of the Public. Comment: I will do my best to find the articles I mentioned from the New Yorker to provide them for you.  One of them is about a particular prisoner who studied the law while incarcerated, and began - in prison - a service to file an appeal for a new trial based on evidence withheld by prosecutors, or discovered after the crime (such as DNA or the recanting of statements by witnesses) that wasn't allowed to be entered into the court deliberations.  That inmate had some real success in doing this work, and once he gained his own freedom using the same studious methods, he joined with an existing legal project doing the same type of work for individuals wrongly convicted.  There are so many procedural errors made, so many cases of prosecutors refusing to reconsider the case in view of new evidence, and so very many cases of poor evidence gathering by police, it makes one cringe at the failures of our legal system.

Comment: All kids all have drivers and triggers, and it's up to the parent to learn what those are in order to get that child properly disciplined, but there's still situations and contexts where you need to show that child a line NO ONE CROSSES has been crossed, because we're in injury or death territory.

I'm reminded of my sister's eldest son, who has about a 150IQ and often shows behaviour that verges on sociopathy. I caught him once, doing the once over to see if adults were paying attention, and then intentionally trying to push his toddler sister down the stairs into the basement. I caught her by her diaper, teetering just at the top of the stairs.  I told her brother I saw him planning it, that I knew it was intentional, and gave him a couple of swats on the ass, over his clothes.

Of course there was a kerfuffle with my sister, but do I think I did the right thing? Absolutely. There's misbehaviour, and then there's malice, and that was malicious and could have killed her.
